bestBHT.bht: With one accord and one mouth, let us glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ. This encourages us to come together in unity, setting aside divisions, so that we may worship God as one. When we join in praising God with one voice, we bring glory to His name. Let us strive for this harmonious worship, honoring our God and Father, for His perfections are truly glorified.

Henry Alford: We may also render this expression, here and elsewhere, ‘God, and the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.’"
But the ordinary rendering, the God and Father.... is preferable on account of its simplicity.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: That, c.—rather, 'that with one accord ye may with one mouth glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ'".
the mind and the mouth of all giving harmonious glory to His name".
What a prayer! And shall this never be realized on earth?
Albert Barnes: That they might join without contention and unkind feeling, in the worship of God.
Divisions, strife, and contention in the church prevent union in worship.
By the desire of honoring 'such' a Father, we should lay aside contentions, and be united in the bands of love.
Philip Schaff: One accord’ results from being ‘of the same mind,’ and is in its turn the source of the praising ‘with one mouth.’"
It is in the utterance of common praise that harmony of feeling finds its highest expression.
The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ. The phrase is the same as in Ephesians 1:3... This thought of praise now becomes the prominent one.
Archibald T. Robertson: With one accord (ομοθυμαδον). Here alone in Paul, but eleven times in Acts (Acts 1:14, etc.).
With one mouth (εν εν στοματ). Vivid outward expression of the unity of feeling.
May glorify (δοξαζητε). Present active subjunctive of δοξαζω, final clause with ινα 'that ye may keep on glorifying.'
John Gill: A cordial and sincere affection for one another is necessary to the worshipping of God with one consent, to a joining together in acts of religious service."
How should there be an agreement of heart and voice, of mind and mouth, in praising God, unless there is a singleness of heart and oneness of affection?"
God is 'glorified' when the perfections of his nature are ascribed unto him; when notice is taken of the works of his hands, and the glory of his majesty, which appears in them.
John Wesley: That ye — Both Jews and gentiles, believing with one mind, and confessing with one mouth.

bhtAttempts.bht: That with one accord and one mouth, we may glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ. The phrase God, and the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ could also be rendered as the God and Father. However, the preference is for the simpler rendering. This verse encourages us to come together in unity, setting aside any divisions or contentions, so that we may worship God as one. When we are of one mind and join together in praising God with one voice, we bring glory to His name. Let us strive for this harmonious worship, giving honor to our God and Father, for it is in these moments that His perfections are truly glorified.
